number of helpful: 6 of 23 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Nothing makes Lovecraft roll in his grave more than this game. I got it, expecting it to actually be clever, but soon found myself wallowing in misery and disappointment. It's supposed to be humorous, but the humor boils down to making silly faces and putting Cthulhu into only mildly ridiculous situations. There's a bit of fourth wall humor, but it's far from adroit. In addition, his out of character reactions only left me cringing. This is a god who makes people insane just by being seen, but here we have him idly chatting with mermaids. It's not funny, it's a failure to draw comedy from an emasculated creature of pure destruction. It's saddening that the only way they could conceive of a Lovecraftian comedy was to completely change the very fabric of what the elder gods are. The only relation this game actually has to Lovecraft's works is in name alone. You could name all of the characters and places differently, it would still be the same game.Gameply-wise, it's as bare bones as an RPG can get. There are no mechanics we haven't seen since the 80's. Every battle can be won by mashing the fight button, and there's a good chance you won't have to grind either. Some of the maps are too long, and the encounter rate will have you groaning over the tedium of having fought this same enemy fifty times in the past twenty minutes. I explored most (I say most because toward the end I just wanted to finish and be done with it) of this game's maps, and there are very few secrets to encounter. In fact, there's very little to the game besides the main quest. There's a few game modes to unlock, but I haven't bothered playing them because of how soul crushing the main game is.If you're an appreciator of Lovecraft's work, or if you think comedy should be witty, or if you like innovative RPG mechanics, this is not the game for you. You're better off spending your money on a hamburger, at least it won't leave you starving and depressed.

number of helpful: 4 of 19 people (21%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Cthulhu Saves the World is an old-school JRPG, and by old school, I mean they ditch all modern innovations, ideas and sensibilities the have accumulated over the years. Which is the point, sure, but it just doesn't add up to much these days, unfortunately. The quirky humour occasionally hits its mark and the characters are, at first, a bit more interesting than the usual JRPG trope characters. However, there doesn't seem to be any more to them except the very superficial quirkiness.Gameplay is the usual old-school JRPG stuff. That is grind. Lots of monotonous grind. In the most baffling design decision I've encountered in a while, your party is completely healed after a won battle, but your mana is not restored. It might not sound so bad, until you realise that without Techs and Magics, your party is consistently and constantly getting beaten. So now you either: A) have to backtrack to a place where you can restore your mana orB) win fights without using mana. Which is not happening, not after the first area or so.Granted, the ability to save anywhere and start random fights almost anytime from the party meny are appreciated, but in the end you still feel like you are wasting your time. The jokes, characters and settings are interesting enough to hold your interest for an hour or two, but eventually the monotony of the gameplay and the frustration of the difficulty curve eat away at your enjoyment.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												This game was painfull to play. I sort of expected that from the price and screenshots but I thought I would give it a shot anyway and I was sourly disapointed. I got to level 20 by spamming the enter key during all fights, speaking of the fights they have tried to do the same thing as Pokemon (And I'm sure a lot of other RPGs) Where all you need to do is walk to find a fight. But who wants to spam the enter key 50 times, every 30 seconds of playing a game? At least in Pokemon you had to walk in long grass... All the dungeons look exactly the same and the whole layout of everything (Menus, battlescreen layout and anything that you need to interact with at all really), are a mix of pointlessness and confusion. I mean, why is "Chat" an option on the main menu? It would make sence if it was an online rpg, but all it triggers is the same conversation with an npc/party member, over and over again. Don't get me wrong I could never make a game at all and for that i respect the efforts that must of gone into this game, but it just wasn't fun to play. At all. I disliked the whole half an hour that i played this. I wanted to find quality in this game but when I couldn't I decided to look into other games of the same producer and I found that "Breath of Death" was almost exactly the same. The same layouts, the same everything with an exception to a few different enimes and npcs. I was pretty much playing the same game, so it gets a strong No from me. Do not recommend.

Posted: September 8, 2013
												CStW certainly gives a bang for your buck; at a mere $3 when not on sale, I can easily recommend it for it's humor (and if you so desire - challenge). You play as Cthulhu, stripped of his dark powers by a mysterious foe. The only way to regain them? Perform great heroic deeds. So begins the misadventures of Cthulhu and his colorful band of misfits you pick up (or groupies as I took to calling them). The game itself is not demanding on your hardware, as one might expect from a retro RPG. The combat is fluid, simple, and rewards your choices - on higher difficulties it can be utterly unforgiving, reminiscent of much older games. And as I’ve said, the game has a great sense of humor about itself. Personally, I found myself compelled to continue playing solely to see what the next joke may be. Grade: B. A solid game that will last you anywhere from 5 to 9 hours on the first campaign, with a few extras to boot. Humor and Combat are it's strong points; the plot is a parody more than anything.

Posted: June 4, 2014
												While not having the fanciest of looks and/or mechanics, this game is highly enjoyable. You will find a lot of lovecraftian references and inside jokes, which you'll enjoy if you're into that stuff, and the game itself is quite a decent classic-old-school RPG. Self aware of the genre limitations, it presents a few features, such as the combo counter or the auto-HP recovery (NOT MP) after every battle, that will make the experience overall better.I also found CSTW highly replayable, since there are two extra modes for the New game, and also a full New Campaign, unlocked once you've completed the game for the first time.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Short answer, buy this game if you like turn-based RPGs. It has a decent sense of humor and some good replay value with the several unlockable gameplay modes, one of which has a main story very different from the original. Besides that, it has several great features hopefully more RPGs could adopt.First feature, everybody gets xp once they join your group, even if they're knocked out or not even in the fight. It annoys me to no end when either of these things are the case. When a character faints and I have to reload just to make sure they aren't left behind xp-wise or the ones I haven't had in the party become nearly useless and end up completely ignored because of the effort it would take to grind them, it really takes me out of the game. Second, every area has a limit on random encounters. Even the overworld has a limit, though it's very high. If you fight the X amount of mobs in the area shown in your menu then there will be no more random encounters. You can also just continue to spam the button "Fight" button to run out the random encounters for the entire area. It Makes exploring a dungeon to try and collect all the loot so much less of a hassle. Each area's amount of random encounters worked out pretty well too. I would usually just finish them off or am left with only a few by the end of it. And if you feel the need to grind a bit afterwards, you can still call more mobs from the menu.Finally, the mobs scale in strength in each area with every fight, peaking by the time you reach the random encounter limit. While the enemies don't scale with each fight in the overworld, they do become stronger for the entirety of the map as you progress through the story.Those aren't the only great mechanics, just the ones other RPGs don't have but should adopt. Very few complaints otherwise. Mainly just how much of a maze the dungeons can become later in the game. Really worth the small price tag.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												Cthulhu Saves The World is a 16-bit old school traditional console style role playing game.  The game has been dated by over 20 years, but still is fun for those who appreciate the older generation style.  The game's battle system is intuitive and encourages magic point management.  The story is linear, and took me about 8 hours with in depth exploration on my first run.  I do encourage playing it on the hardest setting for the most fun, and because the normal setting is a bit easy for the seasoned adventurer.  The replay value is low, as the story is a bit bland for a linear game.  Overall, it was a fun old school romp with a bit of humor and micromanagement, but I'm not going to pick it up again anytime soon.  If you enjoy it, make sure to play Breath Of Death VII, written by the same designer.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												Cthulhu saves the world is a fun little game in the inspiration of JRPG's. I couldn't even begin to describe to you the plot of this wondeful little game. It is one of those, you have to see to believe, kind of game. The combat is fluid, very fast paced. I enjoyed the way this game handles random encounters. There is a counter and whenever you get somewhere, either world map or dungeon, there is a number. For every random encounter you enter and win, the counter goes down by one. Once the counter reads "none", there are no more fights that you will get into randomly. Now, some people might think you can't fight anything at all, but that isn't the case. In the menu there is a fight command. When pressed, you will be thrust into a battle immediately, allowing for leveling if you need to. The characters are silly and enjoyable. Once leveled, there is a little bit of customization with the game, allowing you to choose which level-up bonus you want. You may choose the stats over more HP or the Fire spell over Fire Strike. This allows for, at least the first couple of playthroughs, to be an interesting playthrough, trying different combinations to see which you prefer for the character. The bonus modes I haven't delved into and will update this review when I do so. That said, even without playing them, Cthulhu has stolen my heart with this humurous little game. I hope you pick it up and enjoy it as much as I did.

Hats off to them really.And at the price it is now, GET IT. 110% worth it.Visuals: 8/10Gameplay: 9/10Immersion: 9/10Storyline: 8/10Detail: 7/10(humor: 11/10)Overall: 9.5/10

Posted: March 9, 2014
												Cthulu Saves the World PC ReviewbyMark Nelsonhugpolo@yahoo.comI picked up this game on a Steam Daily Deal for $1 about a month ago and fell in love with this game right away.  I've been playing turning based rpg's since Dragon Warrior and seen most of them come and go.  This game takes those concepts but adds alot of improvements to the old formulas.First of all, the humor is fantastic and carried all thru the game.  The names and descriptions of the creatures encountered will leave you in stitches.  The dialog between the narrartor, Cthulu, and the various party members accquired is well done and alot of HP Lovecraft references are sprinkled about in the right doses.The music is epic and customized to the different areas and dungeons encountered during the game.  It's so good that I only listen to the game music as I'm playing it.  It's dark and dreary and fun and light hearted.The ability to bring in swap in any party members and save the game anytime is a godsend.  Also, you can hold a button and your party will  be able to run thru the open world and dungeons, saving you alot of time.  In every dungeon , there is a fixed amount of random encounters you will  have. (unless you override this)  This making the leveling pacing and amount of grinding required down to a minimum, allowing you to solve any puzzles and gather all the items from every area without being encountered to death by monsters.Cthulu and the party can instantly teleport back to any town they have visited.   Also, you heal all your hps and some magic points after every battle.  This sure beats having to carry a bunch of potions around.Characters level up pretty frequently as you acquire experience and are able to accquire alot of different things such as innate abilties, stat increases, HP and MP increases and spells or techniques.  It's fun to try and decide what to get on each level up, so you could play thru the game multiple times and build the team in different ways to find out what works best for you.The battle simple is very detailed and complex.  Every spell, technique or attack has a certain number of hits which give you combo points.  Certain abilities are called Combo Finishes and the damage dealt is multiplied the number of hits on the combo meter.  You want to get as many hits as fast as you can to use the finishers and end battles quickly.  Mastering this technique help immensely on the boss battles.Monster A.I. is pretty good, creatures will use thier best abilities and grow in strength every round.  If you accidently encounter the wrong mix of creatures and don't or use the right counters it can easily lead to restarts or game over.When you beat the game, you can replay it in a new mode called Cthulu's Angels.  It's a whole new storyline and your main character is one of the girls from the original game tasked by Cthulu to accquire a quarted of hot chicks to save the world.  You accquire portraits of the characters that can be saved and looked at any time.I had a blast with this game and asked Zeboyd Games to please make a sequel with triple the amount of everything.  Do yourself a favor and play this game, it's the most fun RPG you will EVER play in your life!

												Breath of Death 7 and Cthulhu Saves the World should be in your possession RIGHT NOW by any means necessary. They are newschool takes on oldschool RPGs with lots of clever tweaking, great humor, in-jokes, parodies, and all kinds of fun stuff. Nevermind that, there’s also a lot of great stuff going on under the hood.  There are branching skillsets to be acquired through leveling up, all kinds of great and hilarious techniques, an extensive combo system, retries, level scaling, adjustable difficulty, plenty of bonus content, and even an interesting combat system that praises you for quick tactics and punishes you for taking too many turns.

Posted: July 21, 2014
												Honestly, I would recommend this game on the music alone. The battle theme is great for setting the tone of the encounter and the town themes are quite varied. The music aside, this game really is quite funny without forcing humor. It plays on the already ridiculous concept well and just has fun with it.It's nice to see the old style of RPG back but what makes it better is how quick the battles go, in terms of the action boxes. I'm not saying the battles are easy, oh god no. Enemies can hit like semi trucks and knock you flat before you realize what's happening. There are plenty of attacks/spells/combos/what-have-you to pick through so to make a play style that works and is personally appealing.Things can get super tricky, though. The HP restore at the end of each battle is amazing but the lack of potions purchase can  really throw a wrench into the works. I see how the game could be too easy if you could purchase them considering how potions work but it's the last thing that matters when running out in the middle of a fight. The slow MP restore after every battle helps too but it means you have to be careful when using your favorite MP-using attacks. Thankfully, there's a MP restore/save point before every major boss battle so it's not like you'll go into a tough-as-nails battle completely unprepared for it.I'm almost six hours in (up to Kingsport) but I'm loving this game to death. Can't wait to see where it goes.

Posted: February 10, 2014
												A fantastic game for those who love old school JRPGs, and even something for those who do not.Cthulu saves the world is a game that wears its heart on its sleeve. You are Cthulu who has just risen from the depths of the sea to rip the world asunder... only to be smacked down by a evil(?) wizard who drains Cthulu of his power and leaves him on a beach. By eavesdropping on the Narrator, Cthulu finds out that if he becomes a hero, he can regain his powers. So, with a sword, tunic, and the ability to break the forth wall, Cthulu sets out to regain his power by becoming a hero... so he can destroy the world. Along the way he is joined by a cheerful girl who has a crush on him, a necromancer, a man who may or may not be Santa Claus, a mutant cat, and many other silly creatures. The dialouge is silly and full of meta humor, every enemy has some funny quality to them and every bookcase, shelf, drawers, and tombstone has a unique message to go with it.The humor is easily the strong point of the game, but the gameplay is fairly strong too.You move around the world in a party of four and engage in turn based battles and level up before moving along to the next area. While turn based combat may be a draw back for some, CStW has a pretty clever way of dealing with it. All areas including the world map has a set number of encounters that you can fight (15-50 for dungeons, 200 for the world map) that you can see on your party menu. After the number expires, you can freely move around the dungeon unhindered, OR, chose the "FIGHT" command in your party menu to instantly go into a battle to level grind your characters or run out the timer early.The battles themselves are fairly fast paced thanks to the combo system in which every attack on your enemy adds to a counter which powers up finisher moves. On top of that is a branching level up system in which you choose between two "Level up bonuses" which include which states are raised (Do you take 30+ strength or 15+ magic and agility) or two versions of an ability (A spell that hits one enemy for increased damage, or one that hits all enemies for less.) This leads to some nice expirementation with the characters (although two characters felt significantly less useful than others).The game is pretty linear (aside from a few optional dungeons that contain special equipment and silly enemies) and pretty much tells you where you have to go next, but considering you really want to progress the story just to see the next bit of dialouge, this ends up working in the game's favor.The game also comes with Breath of Death 7 the Beginning a similar, if smaller game featuring an undead skeleton swordsman, and Cthulu's Angels, an even sillier sidestory unlocked after you beat the main game that I personally am still working on.For $2.99 this a steal and definitely worth the money.If you have a fondness for retro JRPGs and 4th wall breaking humor, pick this game up.

												Extreme humor and no 4th wall to speak of, Cthulhu Saves The World, along with Breath Of Death VII, are some of the most FUN RPGs available on Steam right now. I mean it. Cthulhu, the embodiement of evil, rises from the sea after aeons of slumber to finally destroy the world... only to find out someone was already expecting him, and loses all of his mythical powers. He wants to destroy the world, but to do it, he must first recover his powers... by saving the world!Aesthetics of old, with a modern twist. Story is as great as it's absurd, it manages to improve on the classic gameplay. You'll really wish they had these simple - yet effective - features back then: they managed to COMPLEMENT the experience without disrupting it, not even a tiny bit. Oh, this also applies to Breath of Death VII.Comes with a bonus campaign (unlocked after you finish the normal game) with an entirely different take on the original story, "Cthulhu's Angels": what happens when the main character already knows the story (since you finished the game with him) and is just too lazy to go through it again? Everything derails into a fight for control over their own DESTINY.Definitely recommend. But play Breath Of Death VII first.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												I didn't think Cthulu Saves the World would suck me in like it did.  The concept seemed a bit novel to me, an old school snes style rpg with Cthulu as the hero.  And the game was so cheap, I figured what the hell.  And I loved it.  From the very beginning the game pulled me in and I didn't want to stop playing.  It was funny, the characters were cool, I liked the overarcing plot, all the Lovecraft references, all the references to old school RPG's, the little facts about the enemies as you fight them, the ability to clear an area of enemies, the counter to let you know how many are left, the button that lets you just start a battle so you can easily level up your characters.  I loved this game from beginning to end.  There is no reason this shouldn't be in every steam owners collection.  Even if you think you won't like it give it a shot.  It's so cheap you're not really going to lose out on much if you don't like it.  Although I honestly wouldn't be able to understand why someone wouldn't love this game.

												Take on the role of a kinder and friendlier Cthulhu as he quests to regain his lost powers by becoming a hero to young and old in this throwback to early JRPG style games. Posted: June 28, 2012
												The Good: Great use of the license, funny dialog, amazing music, varied graphics and environments, lots of attacks to learn and party members to findThe Bad: Graphics grate on your eyes after awhile, gets very hard, random battles bring the experience down a lot, doesn’t require much strategy to win battlesThe Cthulhu series from H.P. Lovecraft hasn’t seen much love in the form of games, but indie developers Zeboyd picked it up and turned it into a whimsical/parody 8 bit RPG and it’s done very well. You play as Cthulhu and pick up many party members along the way, but the whole point of the game is the great dungeon crawling that harkens back to the 80′s. You can attack like any RPG, but you have Tech attacks which are more powerful, magic, and then you can Unite with other members to combine devastating attacks. There are a ton of different attacks you learn when you level up, and you get a choice between two different things to level up with either stats or an attack, so by the end of the game each member has a huge arsenal to use.The game is very close to the mythology with bosses that are from the story, towns named after the exact towns from the stories, plus the art style matches. The music is amazing with sweeping orchestral scores (in 8-bit midi audio mind you) that really moves you and sounds great. The story is hilarious with Cthulhu trying to redeem himself and become a true hero to raise his city of R’lyeh, but his interaction with characters in the world is really funny. Of course the game wouldn’t be complete without a huge over map to explore that has some secret dungeons, plus the environments and dungeons vary with lots of loot and chests to find.However, the game’s biggest flaw is the extreme difficulty later on in the game, as well as the constant random battles which really drag the experience down. The devs tried toning this down by disabling random battles after you do 25 of them, but you will probably go through a dungeon before you hit that number. I also didn’t like how if you don’t level up high enough the end boss is impossible to beat, but each dungeon just really racks up the difficulty and requires you to grind a bit to get through the dungeon. I also didn’t like how you don’t really need a strategy to beat the enemies because you can just use the same one over and over through several dungeons. This causes the feeling of repetition to set in and makes you want the game just to end a little faster.While the visuals are nice and give you a feeling of nostalgia they don’t look good in HD and the lack of battle animations, and everything that goes along with 8-bit graphics grates on your eyes after awhile. However, the Cthulhu license is rarely explored so any game to do so is welcomed, but this game is probably for hardcore RPG fans.--Score: 8/10

Posted: July 6, 2014
												Very fun, albeit simple and very linear turn based RPG. There really aren't any special missions, mini-games, crafting, or other, later RPG game elements, but that doesn't mean this is bad. What this game does have over others is its uniqueness that I've yet to see, if not just heard about, in other games:When you arrive at a new area you have a number of potential random battles to be fought. Once you fight them all you don't have to worry about getting harassed any more! But, if you so choose, you can always instantly get into a fight with enemies, regardless of that "battles remaining" number. This is helpful if you needed to level grind a bit, for example.Winning a fight against your enemies instantly heals your full party to max health. That seems odd at first, but there are definitely a TON of very strong enemies that can kill you from full health very easily. You do NOT, however, restore your mana fully, but only to a very small extent. The mana is a much bigger deal because you primarily use "skills" and "magic" more than you would on basic attacks, which tends to be the common thing in older turn based RPGs.Branching level ups is a fun system that is somewhat in other RPGs, but more so seen as a type of "skill tree" that you see instead, and thus you can't remove and reallocate any point. It's interesting forcing your mage type characters into a fighter role sometimes, for example. The game definitely offers a variety of physical and magical attacks for each character, too, regardless of their normal intended archetype.That's really it, for the most part. There are secret dungeons, which is always a nice thing to have, and the other few unique game aspects, some of which I may have forgotten at the moment, but the game is hands down a great purchase, fully surpassing the "bang for your buck" considering the price tag of $3 which also gives you Breath of Death VII to go along with it.

Posted: July 29, 2015
												This is definitely a game to try out.  The 8-bit graphics are a nice throw back to the old RPGs I enjoyed in my childhood.  There are a plethera of 4th wall breaking moments, and the humor is quite entertaining.  The premise of basically trying to save the world so you can be the one to destroy it is a fresh change from the usual hero tales these games portray.Each dungeon has a set number of random encounters for those who get tired of sudden enemies popping up.  The 'Fight' option in the menu allows you to choose battles when the counter runs out.  Personally I tend to grind levels in games that allow it, so I find myself using 'Fight' often.  This is on Normal difficulty for those wondering which level to choose at the start.I have yet to play the harder difficulties, but this game provides a level for any gamer to enjoy.  I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a good RPG, a new twist on the typical hero story, or just a fun experience.

Posted: July 9, 2015
												You get to play as Cthulhu, some chick with a tentacle-face obsession, an animated sword, a necromancer from the cult of Cthulhu, and Cthulhu's evil space cat who is totally not a cat.11/10 would fhtagn again.SERIOUS REVIEW TIME!CSTW seems to be built around its combat system. It's got some unique features that sets it apart from your average JRPG. One is the combo system. Each attack is worth a certain number of hits, and each hit landed increases your combo counter. You can consume your combo counter with certain finishers that deal a lot of damage, plus even more damage based on your combo count. Personally, I found that its relevance faded as the game progressed.Also present is a soft enrage system. Every turn you spend in the same fight, the enemies get 10% stronger. This forces you to optimize your damage per turn.There's also a nice design feature in its random encounters; once you fight a certain number of battles in an area, you stop getting random encounters there. You can still manually fight enemies in an area as much as you want, but there's no need to, even on hard mode. (Insane mode, however, is a totally different story.)Aside from that, the game is a huge parody of JRPGs in general. You'll see what I mean as you play it.As my recommendation implies, I had fun with it. It was 15 hours long for me.

Posted: December 2, 2011
												This is basically one of the best deals you'll ever find on Steam. Cthulhu Saves the World is fun, jRPG inspired game, that parodies almost everything it can. It's filled from top to bottom with pop-cultural references and jokes.It has fairly clean, pixelated art-style and 8bit soundtrack and sounds... oldschool-ish.As for the fighting system, which takes majority of the game - there isn't much depth in it, but it isn't a problem - there are up to 30 encounters in one dungeon. With such number, even most dedicated strategists would give up, not reaching even half of the game. Instead, game goes for less tactical, fast combat, that still requires some thought, where setting up actions for every member of a party, during one turn takes less than 15 seconds. Because of that, game can (for the most part) get away with its repetitive combat and while it's still a problem, it's nowhere near as big of a problem, that it would be, if they decided with something more complex and time consuming.Beating the game takes around 8hrs... maybe more. After that you unlock 4 "new game+" modes. And it isn't just some simple "play the game with stats from previous game". There is one gamemode, where you play new character, meet new people - which means, new jokes, new dialogue lines. There is one character only mode, there is hardcore gamemode, where you get underpowered characters and finally Overkill - where you level up extremely fast.There is also developer's commentary implemented into a game and full bestiary, that shows and describes many monsters and characters you can meet in game.Finally, you get the game with Breath of Death VII and everything for less than 2€. Totally worth it!

Posted: July 31, 2011
												This game is absolutely brilliant, and hilarious at the same time. I love the characters and their dialogue; i've laughed out loud plenty of times. The game took me just under 12 hours to beat. The battle system requires careful planning at times in order to win. You have to prioritize enemies and skills. Lots of party members to pick up and switch out based on your play style. There are some annoyances in the game, but nothing that prevents you from having a great time. The worst part about the game is the maze-like dungeon design; you will get lost and spin around in circles. Luckily, there is a maximum number of battles for each dungeon, and then you'll stop getting random encounters, meaning you can wander the maze freely to find all the loot and make it to the end. Dungeons feel twice as big as they need to be. Also, after beating the game there are bonus game modes to play. I can't recommend this game enough!

Posted: August 30, 2015
												A very charming homage to the RPG genre and the cthulhu mythos, complete with witty humor/dialogue, diverse cast of playable characters, tons of land to explore, bosses and enemies to conquer, mutiple gameplay strategies to implement on fights and a amazing soundtrack, you got yourself a very, very nice game here at 2.99 USD.Just to give you an idea on the gameplay, if you've been getting your♥♥♥♥♥kicked by enemies and bosses, you actually DON'T have to go on a grind fest or a tedious side quest to find hidden equipment just to beat him/them, unlike many other RPG's. With the combo system along with the insanity and unite mechanics and a huge variety of characters to pull different combinations of moves, I found that just simply changing tactics and experimenting what works and what doesn't, is much better than tedious grinding most RPG's pit you up with.I've beaten the final boss on level 36 in insanity mode, the hardest difficulty, on my first real playthrough and believe me when I say insanity mode is hard, the hours I have don't lie. If that isn't a testament to how the gameplay is set from other traditional RPG's, I don't know what else will convince you.If you're new to RPG's and/or just want something different to the mix, you owe it to yourself to pick this game up.

Posted: December 25, 2014
												First of all, I haven't played this game very much on Steam, but I've played for hours and hours on my iPod and Xbox, so I know what I'm talking about. This is spectacular game. As the dark lord of insanity, you must save the world so that you can destroy it. It's a hilarious premise, as the bad guy must become the good guy so he can get his powers back to destroy the world. Everything about this game is a parody, right down to the enemies' descriptions and the assorted dialogues. If you exect this game to take itself seriously at any point ever, you've completely missed the point. Some reviewers have talked about this game being boring or too easy. I've found that this is not the case. The characters and story are funny and I always want to keep playing to find out what will happen next. I'm playing on normal difficulty, and the battles are somewhat challenging but not overly so, which is exactly what I wanted since I play a lot of hard games (Doom, Prototype, etc etc) and needed a game to just relax with, but it also has two higher difficulty levels if you need a more challenging game like the old-school RPGs. Basically, if you're looking at the screenshots and description and it sounds like something you might like, you should definitely try it. It's a great game, especially if you can get it on sale (like right now). --------------------------------------------------------------------If you enjoy my reviews, why not follow my curation page? Click here to do that thing!

												Take an old-school RPG like Final Fantasy or something. Posted: September 27, 2015
												This game was enjoyable with what could at times be a surprisingly catchy soundtrack and laugh aloud lines, but I found myself becoming weary of the length of some dungeons. They just wound around and spiraled on for what felt like forever with pathways that all kind of looked the same, which made it suuuper easy to get lost and bored. I played with the commentary on (a really cool feature btw, first time I've seen something like this) as I found it interesting to hear about what the devs had to go through in creating some of the dungeons and/or decisions on progressions of the story. It seems they also regretted making some of the dungeons as long as they were, echoing my sentiment earlier.

Posted: September 24, 2015
												This game is actually pretty innovative for an indie RPG.  Dungeons have a limited amount of random encounters, which is actually pretty much the right amount for a normal run of a dungeon.  Your HP gets fully healed after battles and MP regenerates some, but in exchange, battles are quite a bit harder and you'll probably be using spells and skills a lot more than normal.  When you level up, you gain stats like normal, but you also get a choice between 2 bonuses, which can change the way a character plays.  Usually, it's a choice between different stat bonuses, 2 similar skills made slightly differently, or even a skill the character may or may not use and a decent stat bonus.The game has a lot of good humor.  I recommend checking every book shelf and dresser for funny dialogue.There's also multiple different characters with different strenghts and abilities to change your tactics.As a big fan of Dragon Quest games and other RPGs that involve more strategy than grinding, I highly recommend this game.

Posted: September 23, 2015
												If you're reading this, I assume you've also checked the page for Breath of Death VII. I got both of the games in a bundle, and this is my take on the two. They're great. I'm not really a fan of the turn-based rpg genre, but BoDVII eased me into the combat style and CStW expanded upon it wonderfully. If you get both I would recommend playing BoDVII first. What you may be asking is what the difference between the two is.BoDVII is shorter. It took me about 4 hours to complete once, whereas CStW took me 10. BoDVII however has more believable characters and story. CStW's characters are cheesy and really insincere in comparison, and they literally have to break the fourth wall in order to make the plot work. BoDVII may have been shorter, but it was just the right length. CStW was longer, but the length feel like its there just so there can be more of it, not to expand upon the quality of the game in any way. It has more content, but doesn't do much with it. CStW's combat system is better though. It is much more complex and features the ability to put different party members into your fighting group of 4. BoDVII only had 4 party members.Final Verdict: Breath of Death VII and Cthulhu Saves the World are both amazing games. If I had to pick one over the other, I would choose BoDVII. If you can geth both though, do it, they're cheap.

Posted: December 23, 2014
												It's exactly what it appears to be: a retro JRPG with a completely silly plot.  What may not be so obvious is that there are unique, well-designed aspects to the game mechanics: among other things, there are a limited number of random battles in each area, level-up bonuses are branching rather than pre-determined, and monsters grow stronger each round, which makes combat fast-paced and brutal.  There are even various challenge game modes, and one with a full alternate plot, to improve replay value.It's not a great game by any stretch, but it's entertaining enough, and the price is right.

Posted: November 10, 2012
												[Spoiler-Free Review]The spiritual successor to Breath of Death VII, Cthulhu Saves the World turns it's parodial focus to Lovecraft's ultimate evil-doer and dares you to pull it's finger.In addition to the much improved engine which brings the series more in line with it's 16-bit forefathers (bridges are now beautifully rendered), Cthulhu features a fleshed out campaign with an all-new cast of characters and plenty of post game bonus content for completionists everywhere. There's even a second quest with an all-new storyline once you've completed the first.I'll admit I'm not very well-versed in Cthulhuian lore and felt the humour was a bit too forced and goofy at times as a result. Where Breath of Death was sharp and witty, Cthulhu was brazen, outlandish and downright silly. Like a teenager trying to impress his friends with useless and mundane "skills".The music is still unconventionally memorable (hard rock cave music?) and nods to Zeboyd's history are strewn throughout the game. As with the first game, the optional developer's commentary is enlightening and entertaining and fits perfectly within a game unafraid to break the fourth wall.Cthulhu Saves the World is a bit of an enigma however, while I enjoyed it less than Breath of Death VII, I'm willing to admit it's probably more to do with my lack of understanding of the source material. I ended up playing this game nearly two times longer than I did Breath of Death VII and enjoyed most of it. Chances are if you've played the first game, you'll want to help Cthulhu Save the World too.Um... hurry?

Posted: January 31, 2015
												This is a fun, retro RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously.  However, it's not without problems.The plot is quirky and the dialog full of one-liners and bad puns.  The game is strongest during dialogue, with back and forths between the main characters and the narrator.  There are also plenty of lines when examing bookshelves and chest of drawers that will make you chuckle too.This game has great music (just had to make sure I mentioned that).The main problem I had with this game was the random encounters on places that weren't the world map.  These areas are giant labyrinths and you end up wandering around, lost, while getting pestered with battles.  After a while, you're strong enough that there's no great risk to these battles (although to be fair, I only played on Normal difficulty so other ones might be better in this regard) so you end up sighing, mashing Return and waiting for the damned battle to finish.A few hours into the game, I ended up working around the too frequent random battles by going to the start of each new area and selecting 'Fight' from the menu (which forces a new random encounter), getting all of them out of the way one after another.  This is a bit of a shame.I found myself surprisingly engaged in the story and characters but occasionally got yanked out of that state of mind with the grindy nature of the game.  Still, I'm glad I played this.This game is worth buying if you're into RPGs and are at a loss of the next one to play.

												Take an old-school RPG like Final Fantasy or something. Now, take the frustrating elements (save points, grinding, random battles, stocking up on HP and mana potions at every town, etc) and throw them away/make them bearable. If you're at all a retro RPG fan, you need to play this game.If you're not a retro RPG fan, you still need to play this game for the funniness of the dialogue and the soundtrack.If you're still not convinced, the price is really low for such a good RPG.If you're STILL not convinced... Posted: May 15, 2015
												A wonderful satire, r'lyeh great writing, offset slightly by JRPG combat that plagues so many games of the period this game is fond of satirizing. Still, a thoroughly enjoyable experience even for someone like me that hates this sort of combat style -- it was worth it (I think this is the only Turn-based JRPG combat game I've stuck with till the end since Pokemon Red).A love letter to the Cthulhu mythos and on the levels of the Stanley Parable in its ability to poke fun at the narrator-protagonist relationship and contract. A worthwhile journey, for a low price, that doesn't overstay its welcome due to dozens of hours of grinding or doing horribly mundane things. As a bonus you'll get to learn the names of a few Cthulhu mythos characters!

Posted: March 27, 2013
												For all those people who love old school Role Playing Games and those who feel that the genre needs to be a bit faster paced this is that game for you. Cthulhu Saves the World is a fantastic indie RPG, that last about 10 hours, where you play of the lord of insanity right when he loses all of his powers. In order to get them back he needs to become a hero and save the world (several times). Along the way he meets many characters that are fun to play with and add depth to conversations. Gameplay is turn based combat in first person with text representing up to 4 characters that you can have in combat. Each character can focus on strength or magic so you can customize their stats with gear and 2 different choices when they level. They can also learn or enhance spells depending on the choices and all characters gain experience regardless of if they were in combat or not. One of my favorite features that i wish were in more RPG's is the limited encounter system. In each area you can only have to fight so many enemies until the game decides you have fought enough, you can still fight enemies by selecting fight but this is not required. The humor in Cthulhu is some of the best in video games. There are references everywhere and the way the characters interact is just so great. There is no reason not to get this game. It cost less than lunch and comes with a bonus RPG that is almost as good. Get this game if you want a fun, funny and fast RPG. P.S. 4 new game modes after you beat the game.

Posted: September 8, 2013
												CStW certainly gives a bang for your buck; at a mere $3 when not on sale, I can easily recommend it for it's humor (and if you so desire - challenge). You play as Cthulhu, stripped of his dark powers by a mysterious foe. The only way to regain them? Perform great heroic deeds. So begins the misadventures of Cthulhu and his colorful band of misfits you pick up (or groupies as I took to calling them). The game itself is not demanding on your hardware, as one might expect from a retro RPG. The combat is fluid, simple, and rewards your choices - on higher difficulties it can be utterly unforgiving, reminiscent of much older games. And as I’ve said, the game has a great sense of humor about itself. Personally, I found myself compelled to continue playing solely to see what the next joke may be. Grade: B. A solid game that will last you anywhere from 5 to 9 hours on the first campaign, with a few extras to boot. Humor and Combat are it's strong points; the plot is a parody more than anything.

Posted: July 21, 2014
												Honestly, I would recommend this game on the music alone. The battle theme is great for setting the tone of the encounter and the town themes are quite varied. The music aside, this game really is quite funny without forcing humor. It plays on the already ridiculous concept well and just has fun with it.It's nice to see the old style of RPG back but what makes it better is how quick the battles go, in terms of the action boxes. I'm not saying the battles are easy, oh god no. Enemies can hit like semi trucks and knock you flat before you realize what's happening. There are plenty of attacks/spells/combos/what-have-you to pick through so to make a play style that works and is personally appealing.Things can get super tricky, though. The HP restore at the end of each battle is amazing but the lack of potions purchase can  really throw a wrench into the works. I see how the game could be too easy if you could purchase them considering how potions work but it's the last thing that matters when running out in the middle of a fight. The slow MP restore after every battle helps too but it means you have to be careful when using your favorite MP-using attacks. Thankfully, there's a MP restore/save point before every major boss battle so it's not like you'll go into a tough-as-nails battle completely unprepared for it.I'm almost six hours in (up to Kingsport) but I'm loving this game to death. Can't wait to see where it goes.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												Very fun, albeit simple and very linear turn based RPG. There really aren't any special missions, mini-games, crafting, or other, later RPG game elements, but that doesn't mean this is bad. What this game does have over others is its uniqueness that I've yet to see, if not just heard about, in other games:When you arrive at a new area you have a number of potential random battles to be fought. Once you fight them all you don't have to worry about getting harassed any more! But, if you so choose, you can always instantly get into a fight with enemies, regardless of that "battles remaining" number. This is helpful if you needed to level grind a bit, for example.Winning a fight against your enemies instantly heals your full party to max health. That seems odd at first, but there are definitely a TON of very strong enemies that can kill you from full health very easily. You do NOT, however, restore your mana fully, but only to a very small extent. The mana is a much bigger deal because you primarily use "skills" and "magic" more than you would on basic attacks, which tends to be the common thing in older turn based RPGs.Branching level ups is a fun system that is somewhat in other RPGs, but more so seen as a type of "skill tree" that you see instead, and thus you can't remove and reallocate any point. It's interesting forcing your mage type characters into a fighter role sometimes, for example. The game definitely offers a variety of physical and magical attacks for each character, too, regardless of their normal intended archetype.That's really it, for the most part. There are secret dungeons, which is always a nice thing to have, and the other few unique game aspects, some of which I may have forgotten at the moment, but the game is hands down a great purchase, fully surpassing the "bang for your buck" considering the price tag of $3 which also gives you Breath of Death VII to go along with it.

Posted: November 28, 2011
												It's hard to argue with Steam Sales.  When I saw this game in a 2-for-1 pack with Breath of Death VII, discounted from $2.99 to $1, most of the argument had been made for me.  I watched the trailer for both games, and decided that taking a dollar's risk was worth it.Boy, was I right.If you're a fan of old-school style RPGs, humor, or Cthulhu, then this game alone would be worth $2.99.  The fourth wall is shattered early on to kick off the plot, and allows for some hilarious exchanges between the characters and narrator.  The combat system is easy-to-grasp, but relatively simplistic, allowing the player enough customization to feel that they are in control and effectively strategize, but staying sidelined enough to keep the focus on the story.Recommended for anyone who enjoys old-school RPGs, or mocking them.  Or, fans of Cthulhu.  That much should be obvious from the title.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												This is an odd title, to say the least.  It's a solid game...  But seems to exist less as a game than as a parody of a game.Cthulhu Saves the World is very reminiscent of the old Final Fantasy games.  Similar gameplay mechanics.  Similar character and storyline tropes.  Except...  You aren't actually playing as a hero out to save the world from an ancient evil.  You're playing as an ancient evil out to destroy the world.The graphics are delightfully nostalgic.  Simple 2D sprites that immediately brought me back to the old Dragon Quest and Final Fantasy games.The combat mechanics, also, hearken back to those classic games.But the humor is delightfully fresh.  Lots of fun being poked at the CRPG genre.  Lots of self-aware humor.It's a simple, fun game.  And cheap.  But I'm not sure if it'd hold my attention long enough to actually play through to the end.

Posted: July 21, 2014
												Honestly, I would recommend this game on the music alone. The battle theme is great for setting the tone of the encounter and the town themes are quite varied. The music aside, this game really is quite funny without forcing humor. It plays on the already ridiculous concept well and just has fun with it.It's nice to see the old style of RPG back but what makes it better is how quick the battles go, in terms of the action boxes. I'm not saying the battles are easy, oh god no. Enemies can hit like semi trucks and knock you flat before you realize what's happening. There are plenty of attacks/spells/combos/what-have-you to pick through so to make a play style that works and is personally appealing.Things can get super tricky, though. The HP restore at the end of each battle is amazing but the lack of potions purchase can  really throw a wrench into the works. I see how the game could be too easy if you could purchase them considering how potions work but it's the last thing that matters when running out in the middle of a fight. The slow MP restore after every battle helps too but it means you have to be careful when using your favorite MP-using attacks. Thankfully, there's a MP restore/save point before every major boss battle so it's not like you'll go into a tough-as-nails battle completely unprepared for it.I'm almost six hours in (up to Kingsport) but I'm loving this game to death. Can't wait to see where it goes.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												Overall I felt that Cthulhu Saves the World is a weaker game than Breath of Death VII. Zeboyd's first game was more of a genre parody of JRPGs, while Cthulhu feels like a Lovecraft parody that happens to take the form of a JRPG - and not a very strong parody at that. It's silly Lovecraft, and not a clever overturning of Lovecraft's themes and conventions (like Breath of Death was for JRPGs). But that doesn't mean it's not funny and enjoyable. The fast levelling and combat did a good job of keeping me engaged, and the game is that kind that's short in a good way, so that it doesn't overstay its welcome. Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/09/cthulhu-saves-world.html

Posted: May 29, 2015
A Paladin's Steam Review: Cthulhu Saves the World. Perhaps the Last jRPG I’ll Ever ReviewGenre: 2D jRPGDeveloped & Published by: Zeboyd Games Platform: Windows only. Business Model: Duo Pack PurchaseCopy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay ThoughtsCthulhu Saves the World is a game about Cthulhu, the great dark lord of the sith, a being so terrible that just being around him makes everyone go insane. So, how does one stop such unstoppable madness? Have a stranger zap his power away. Then make him become a true hero and his powers will return to him. Yeah, the plot is rather...unexplained. But that’s not important because we have madder things to deal with! Like groupies, heroes, undead monsters and Cthulhu saving the world. It’s a pretty fun and funny time, with plenty of references to go around. This is a 2D jRPG with a minimal upgrade system for armor, weapons and skills. Combat SystemCthulhu builds upon the combat system designed in Breath of Death VII. Refining the lightning-quick turn-based combat to a new level. Now, there’s a new system called Insanity. When enemies become insane via certain abilities you can use, they take and give out double the normal damage. It’s a tricky trade-off to make sure you don’t accidentally power up an enemy before you can strike a killing blow. There’s also retries to start a battle over if you messed up too badly and some tweaks to status effects to make them more useful. There’s also a fairly basic upgrade system. Everytime you level up, you get a choice of abilities to select and hopefully improve your combat performance. (Though I get the feeling that the wrong choices could really hurt you without you knowing it). Weapons and armor can also be upgraded from the shop and loot found in the world. There’s usually only a couple of choices per weapon and armor “level” so it comes down to what stat you prefer the most. BoredomI found that after 10 hours, the combat system was becoming too dull to work through. Half the battles were a cakewalk and the other half the difficulty would seem to suddenly spike and I would die repeatedly. It didn’t help that there was a constant rinse-and-repeat of entering battle, select the same combo of attacks and win/lose. Which has made me realize that perhaps jRPGs as a genre aren’t for me anymore. I used to enjoy them a lot when I was younger. Now? I find the repetition tedious. It’s a case where minimal visuals may have worked against the game, because there’s no interesting eye candy to watch. It’s a trade-off. PC SettingsCthulhu is very well optimized and won’t strain your system at all. Crashing and bugs should be rare as well. The devs clearly knew how to make a polished jRPG. That being said, the game only supports 1280x720 and 640x360 in addition to fullscreen mode. Frame rate is also capped at 60FPS. There aren’t any other visual settings to be found here. There’s also no mouse support but that’s largely unimportant. Remapping of keys is here as well as support for controllers. Separate volume controls exist as well. Largely bare-boned and mostly I just miss resolution options. Outside of that, it’s just fine. Final ThoughtsI want to like Cthulhu Saves the World. I really do. But I think CSTW has indicated that the jRPG genre might not be for me anymore. The premise of Cthulhu stripped of his powers until he becomes a great hero is very amusing. But the game’s dry combat system is simply too boring for me to enjoy it. Especially when I take the experience grind into account. That all said, if jRPGs are your kind of genre, Cthulhu Saves the World is well worth checking out. Especially since it’s a combo pack with the other well done jRPG, Breath of Death VII: The Beginning. A Paladin’s Steam Review: Breath of Death VII: The BeginningRead this review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

Posted: June 28, 2013
												I have played and completed the campaign in 'normal' mode.In the beginning, when the party contained only two characters, battles were challenging. But after the third and fourth member had joined my party, the standard battles were too easy because my party was too strong for its enemies. However in the end, in o'Riles's castle it got really tough again. So after completing the campaign I can say that the difficulty is o.k., sometimes too easy but other times really hard.I like the humor in the game.I didn't like the interuptions with battles while I try to find my way through a dungeon or castle. Because after the battle I forgot which corridor I came from and which direction I was planning to go. The game offers no map that shows were I have already been. Such a map would really help!I liked the battle system: it offered enough tactics in spite of it's simple text base. It reminded me of playing 'The Bard's Tale'. I enjoyed picking the right specialist for the party and developing his/her skills.I really enjoyed playing through the campaign.After finishing the campaign some interesting bonus modes are unlocked, e.g. the 'highlander' mode in which you may only have one character at a time in your party while gaining more experience. Maybe I'll check these when I feel the urge to play it again.[my ranking: 8/10]

												I'm glad I got it on sale. I'll say that much.I wanted to like this game. I'm admittedly a pretty big Lovecraftian nerd, and I appreciated the humorous nods towards the mythos. That's...more or less the only positive thing I can say about this game.The story is garbage, from what little of it I've seen. The gameplay is in a generic turn-based RPG style. The map design is absolutely horrendous. Any stretch of any area looks exactly the same as every other. The tongue-in-cheek humor gets old. Very, very old. The same jokes that were hardly funny the first time are repeated over and over ad absurdum. It felt like a chore just playing it.If all of this sounds attractive to you, by all means. Get the game when it's on sale, or something. But I wouldn't recommend paying the full price for it.

Posted: December 5, 2013
												Fantastic little RPG! It's packed full of fun characters and environments, with an enjoyable battle system and level-up system to boot! Its presentation is great too with appealing graphics and some great SNES-era style music. In addition to all this, the game has great replay value with various difficulty levels and game modes, and some other neat features such as character bromides, a bestiary and a full developer commentary. Finally, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the exceptional writing in this game. Most RPGs fall flat on their face when attempting humour. Cthulu Saves the World is one of the only RPGs I've played that succeeds at being funny, even hilarious at times, with well-written dialogue and great comedic timing.For only £1.99 or less (I got it for 50p in a sale) there's really no reason not to own this game. I really can't recommend this one enough. Pick up Breath of Death while you're at it.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												I didn't think Cthulu Saves the World would suck me in like it did.  The concept seemed a bit novel to me, an old school snes style rpg with Cthulu as the hero.  And the game was so cheap, I figured what the hell.  And I loved it.  From the very beginning the game pulled me in and I didn't want to stop playing.  It was funny, the characters were cool, I liked the overarcing plot, all the Lovecraft references, all the references to old school RPG's, the little facts about the enemies as you fight them, the ability to clear an area of enemies, the counter to let you know how many are left, the button that lets you just start a battle so you can easily level up your characters.  I loved this game from beginning to end.  There is no reason this shouldn't be in every steam owners collection.  Even if you think you won't like it give it a shot.  It's so cheap you're not really going to lose out on much if you don't like it.  Although I honestly wouldn't be able to understand why someone wouldn't love this game.

Posted: June 28, 2012
												The Good: Great use of the license, funny dialog, amazing music, varied graphics and environments, lots of attacks to learn and party members to findThe Bad: Graphics grate on your eyes after awhile, gets very hard, random battles bring the experience down a lot, doesn’t require much strategy to win battlesThe Cthulhu series from H.P. Lovecraft hasn’t seen much love in the form of games, but indie developers Zeboyd picked it up and turned it into a whimsical/parody 8 bit RPG and it’s done very well. You play as Cthulhu and pick up many party members along the way, but the whole point of the game is the great dungeon crawling that harkens back to the 80′s. You can attack like any RPG, but you have Tech attacks which are more powerful, magic, and then you can Unite with other members to combine devastating attacks. There are a ton of different attacks you learn when you level up, and you get a choice between two different things to level up with either stats or an attack, so by the end of the game each member has a huge arsenal to use.The game is very close to the mythology with bosses that are from the story, towns named after the exact towns from the stories, plus the art style matches. The music is amazing with sweeping orchestral scores (in 8-bit midi audio mind you) that really moves you and sounds great. The story is hilarious with Cthulhu trying to redeem himself and become a true hero to raise his city of R’lyeh, but his interaction with characters in the world is really funny. Of course the game wouldn’t be complete without a huge over map to explore that has some secret dungeons, plus the environments and dungeons vary with lots of loot and chests to find.However, the game’s biggest flaw is the extreme difficulty later on in the game, as well as the constant random battles which really drag the experience down. The devs tried toning this down by disabling random battles after you do 25 of them, but you will probably go through a dungeon before you hit that number. I also didn’t like how if you don’t level up high enough the end boss is impossible to beat, but each dungeon just really racks up the difficulty and requires you to grind a bit to get through the dungeon. I also didn’t like how you don’t really need a strategy to beat the enemies because you can just use the same one over and over through several dungeons. This causes the feeling of repetition to set in and makes you want the game just to end a little faster.While the visuals are nice and give you a feeling of nostalgia they don’t look good in HD and the lack of battle animations, and everything that goes along with 8-bit graphics grates on your eyes after awhile. However, the Cthulhu license is rarely explored so any game to do so is welcomed, but this game is probably for hardcore RPG fans.--Score: 8/10

Posted: July 12, 2012
												Interesting take on the RPG, where the dark lord of the elder gods becomes the foil for the perfect and most unlikely of anti-heros. I still prefer the writing of disgea better in that sense. The mechanics work, not the best and are very limited but as far as indie titles it's a welcome addition to any collection.

Posted: November 4, 2012
												As the obvious direct spiritual successor to Breath of Death VII, this is what you'd expect -- another old console JRPG-style game that's still more a parody than anything, but this one's a touch more serious, at least design-wise.  The graphics, especially in-battle, have been upped from feeling like a late NES game to an early SNES game, the music is a touch higher in quality, the gameplay is made slightly more interesting with the Insanity system (basically a way to make enemies die faster but also hurt you more), more characters to choose from, a more robust Unite system and many other improvements.  Add the comic-style cutscenes and overall larger game and you SHOULD have an overall superior experience, right?Unfortunately, the killing blow for this game is the massive, abhorrently mazelike dungeons.   They are far too large and far too numerous, and are bad from the very beginning.  This one element makes the game far less enjoyable than it could have been, but it's still okay.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												Overall I felt that Cthulhu Saves the World is a weaker game than Breath of Death VII. Zeboyd's first game was more of a genre parody of JRPGs, while Cthulhu feels like a Lovecraft parody that happens to take the form of a JRPG - and not a very strong parody at that. It's silly Lovecraft, and not a clever overturning of Lovecraft's themes and conventions (like Breath of Death was for JRPGs). But that doesn't mean it's not funny and enjoyable. The fast levelling and combat did a good job of keeping me engaged, and the game is that kind that's short in a good way, so that it doesn't overstay its welcome. Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/09/cthulhu-saves-world.html

Posted: June 17, 2014
												Cthulhu Saves The World is basically Breath of Death VII with a Lovecraftian theme, some minor gameplay additions to add depth, an expanded scope, and some bonus modes. This might sound like a negative statement, but I view it as a positive one. Breath of Death VII's forumla wasn't broken, so there was no need to try and fix it. Once again, the combat is quick but challenging, all the classic JRPG elements show up to be satirized, and the writing and humor take center stage. And most importantly, it executes all of these things well. When you consider that this is in a double pack with Breath of Death VII for a mere $3 when it's not on sale, there's no excuse for not taking a chance on this game. Must-buy.Two final thoughts:1. Bring on Cosmic Star Heroine2. I'm not afraid to admit that I have a crush on October.

Posted: July 19, 2011
												Harking back to the yesteryear of the early 90's, Cthulhu Saves the World is a 2D RPG that comically parodies the age old genre while faithfully remaining true to its roots as well. An indepth leveling system combined with luscious 2D pixel art go well with the tongue in cheek styled humor of the antithetic Cthulhu who has been placed in the titular role as a "true hero" (against his will, of course). Along the way, he'll come across unlikely allies that will join him in his journey to save the world...only to destroy it with madness upon regaining his stolen power.I bought this in a bundle with Breath of Death VII for only $3. However, that deal may expire soon. Even still, this game is well worth the asking price of a measly 3 bucks and a true treat to any that yearn for a RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously or wishes to go back to the 90's, if only for just a little while.

Posted: November 28, 2011
												It's hard to argue with Steam Sales.  When I saw this game in a 2-for-1 pack with Breath of Death VII, discounted from $2.99 to $1, most of the argument had been made for me.  I watched the trailer for both games, and decided that taking a dollar's risk was worth it.Boy, was I right.If you're a fan of old-school style RPGs, humor, or Cthulhu, then this game alone would be worth $2.99.  The fourth wall is shattered early on to kick off the plot, and allows for some hilarious exchanges between the characters and narrator.  The combat system is easy-to-grasp, but relatively simplistic, allowing the player enough customization to feel that they are in control and effectively strategize, but staying sidelined enough to keep the focus on the story.Recommended for anyone who enjoys old-school RPGs, or mocking them.  Or, fans of Cthulhu.  That much should be obvious from the title.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												Cthulhu is a parody that manages to succeed not only with its humor but also with its gameplay.  It manages to capture the essence of old school JRPGs while avoiding some of their pitfalls.  It's got the music, the graphics, and the interface that we all remember, but with the added bonus of capping random encounters in an area. Posted: June 26, 2014
												I personally do not know much about Lovcraftian lore, save what I have gleaned from an alll-night session of Arkham Horror with friends. Prior knowledge is not needed to enjoy this game though, important information (Cthuhlu is an elder god who cares little as to the fates of humans) is quickly explained and then pushed to the side as the jokes roll in. Four chapters in so far, and the laughter has not subsided. They come in the conversations between party members, the descriptions of the enemies, and in the insanity bestowed upon ones' enemies. The gameplay is a fairly simple turn-based RPG, with options chosen from a menu. The story is simple too: Cthuhlu is leading a bumbling (or maybe I'm the bumbler?) group of adventurers in order to become a hero so he may regain the power to destroy the earth. Currently it is less than a dollar due to the steam sale, but I believe it is worth the mere three-dollar full price. Zeboyd Games have created a delightful game that will keep a player entertained for as long as one is playing it.

Posted: March 27, 2013
												For all those people who love old school Role Playing Games and those who feel that the genre needs to be a bit faster paced this is that game for you. Cthulhu Saves the World is a fantastic indie RPG, that last about 10 hours, where you play of the lord of insanity right when he loses all of his powers. In order to get them back he needs to become a hero and save the world (several times). Along the way he meets many characters that are fun to play with and add depth to conversations. Gameplay is turn based combat in first person with text representing up to 4 characters that you can have in combat. Each character can focus on strength or magic so you can customize their stats with gear and 2 different choices when they level. They can also learn or enhance spells depending on the choices and all characters gain experience regardless of if they were in combat or not. One of my favorite features that i wish were in more RPG's is the limited encounter system. In each area you can only have to fight so many enemies until the game decides you have fought enough, you can still fight enemies by selecting fight but this is not required. The humor in Cthulhu is some of the best in video games. There are references everywhere and the way the characters interact is just so great. There is no reason not to get this game. It cost less than lunch and comes with a bonus RPG that is almost as good. Get this game if you want a fun, funny and fast RPG. P.S. 4 new game modes after you beat the game.

												This and Breath of Death VII are two games that demonstrate an absolutely simple but at the same time revolutionary concept for JRPGs and gaming in general that I think more big time companies and other indie developers should take up on while still making games of the calibur they do now.In short, I speak of shortness, but not being cut off. Cthulhu Saves the World does this within each of its campaigns but provides plenty of enjoyable replayability in its multiple game modes, unlockable content, simple on the surface but deep under the skin combat systems and absolutely -awesome- wit and charm. Posted: December 25, 2014
												First of all, I haven't played this game very much on Steam, but I've played for hours and hours on my iPod and Xbox, so I know what I'm talking about. This is spectacular game. As the dark lord of insanity, you must save the world so that you can destroy it. It's a hilarious premise, as the bad guy must become the good guy so he can get his powers back to destroy the world. Everything about this game is a parody, right down to the enemies' descriptions and the assorted dialogues. If you exect this game to take itself seriously at any point ever, you've completely missed the point. Some reviewers have talked about this game being boring or too easy. I've found that this is not the case. The characters and story are funny and I always want to keep playing to find out what will happen next. I'm playing on normal difficulty, and the battles are somewhat challenging but not overly so, which is exactly what I wanted since I play a lot of hard games (Doom, Prototype, etc etc) and needed a game to just relax with, but it also has two higher difficulty levels if you need a more challenging game like the old-school RPGs. Basically, if you're looking at the screenshots and description and it sounds like something you might like, you should definitely try it. It's a great game, especially if you can get it on sale (like right now). --------------------------------------------------------------------If you enjoy my reviews, why not follow my curation page? Posted: April 15, 2014
												This game is basically the same as Breath of Death VII.  RPG-lite with quick turn-based combat, minimal resource management, and a simplistic light-hearted story sprinkled with puns.  You fully heal HP after every fight and the game emphasizes on quickly finishing fights by making enemies stronger over each round and giving you more MP restoration for battles that end in a few turns.  Forced random encounters in each zone are limited so if you run that number out you don't have to fight anymore in that zone unless you choose to.  The music in this one was actually pretty good in some places, and as with BoDVII you can conveniently remap the controls to work on one hand so you can relax or eat something while you play.  I accrued about 8 hours of playtime and did a few extra dungeons.  Not a bad game, especially since its comes pretty cheap.
