Posted: March 8, 2015
												Fun throwback to ye olden days RPG, or JRPG if you prefer. The game is in the style of the old Final Fantasy games which for me does have some nostalgia value since I remember playing FF 4 or 5 on my old Gameboy Color. But the game itself is pretty entertaining. The story is amusing, I've had a few good laughs throughout my playthrough so far. The aesthetic is fairly good if you like the 16 bit style. I've had a couple problems with the UI but nothing major after I got used to it, my biggest complaint is that the game doesn't seem to want to let you Alt-tab out of it. One thing you DO NEED TO KNOW is that if you lose a fight and don't want to spend a 1-up to try again, hitting backspace to quit will force you to reload your last save file. So save frequently and if you're thinking about quiting out of a fight consider how long it's been since your last save. :PThe dungeons are maybe a bit too large and somes feel convoluted, I definitely got lost a time or two. And due to the nature of exploring through being constantly attacked with random encounters this can mean the game can drag on a little. Personally I've enjoyed the game enough this has not bothered me, but if you're expecting this to be a quick little experience you may find otherwise. So far I've played probably around 8 or 10 hours on Hard difficulty and I still haven't reached the ending.Speaking of difficulty, I found the game a bit too easy on Normal so I had to stick it out through Hard even though at the start MP management is a pain (mana points). Now that's almost disappeared as a concern since all my characters have over 100 MP and some even over 300 and the spell costs didn't really grow in proportion, but I consider that a good thing. Some dungeons are still long enough that I'm starting to run out of MP near the end, for a couple I've even had to go back to town and come back to refill on MP. It can be a bit tedious but Normal difficulty just felt too easy. Though if you just want to blitz through the game just for the story, then going on Normal or Easy is probably the way to do so. The character development in terms of combat is interesting because it genuinely does feel like it's possible to have your characters fill the role you wish them to, at least to a certain point. For example your first party member Umi at first seems like a great mage but I think she's actually a better fighter/support and should focus on Str which will really come into form when you pick up Thor's Call somewhere above lvl 20. As she levels you can try to push her down the mage tree but I honestly don't think she'll ever be as good as October. Similarly it's possible to try to make Cthulhu a mage, but I don't think he'd do all that well either, and for both characters I feel this is mostly due to a lack of spells. October gets the access to the full wizard toolkit, while Umi and Cthulhu can only really pick up the occasional spell. And unfortunately it seems once you make a level up choice there is no way to alter your choices, so later on you may regret spending points in one direction or another. Generally most characters feel useful in some capacity or another, except for maybe Paws. He has extremely high Agility, can toggle the enemy group's insanity on or off, and that's about it? He just seems to be lacking any combat skills to make him effective and even when he gets a couple they don't really do enough damage. The insanity bit is interesting but I don't see a reason to bring him along when Dacre can support much better, both Umi and October are better Mages, and Umi, October, and Sharpe all do way more damage. He's a sort of Jack off All Trades, Master of None in that he can do a bit of just about everything, but all of it is kinda weak. I think he'd have been better if he had been more focused on something.Overall I would say the combat is competent, which is fine since I think humor is meant to also be a large part of the attraction and in my opinion it works. And I do like the fact you can skip through all the combat text if you so desire, so combat only takes as long as you want it to. Though some of the harder fights did require me to pay attention. The Insanity mechanic is pretty interesting in that you can get buffs from enemies being insane and it looks funny/cool, and I know the devs intended for it to be a double edged sword, but I tend to find the edge that cuts back at me is a bit too sharp. It's fun seeing October cast Void on an insane group and do 1400 dmg in aoe to a massive crowd, or seeing Cthulhu Dark Strike an insane enemy for like 3k dmg, but it's not so much fun when the enemies start throwing their insanity buffed nukes at you and party members start dropping like flies. All in all I've found it better to avoid turning most enemies insane and just mess around with it from time to time rather than trying to rely on it. Steam says I have played 12 hours but it's really more like 8-10, but I still haven't finished the game or tried the extra game modes so I hope to be entertained even more by the mighty Cthulhu as he strives to be a true hero. tl;dr version: A funny, quirky game in the style of oldschool RPGs like the early Final Fantasy titles. Not perfect but it's fun enough to kill a good few hours and has a generous amount of content at a generous price, so imo well worth effort.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												I think the best word for this game is "cute".  The writing is certainly fun, and the pixel art graphics have a certain nostalgia and neat style to them.  For the most part, the actual combat is uninteresting; I never got into the old school RPG games that featured combat like this (where you can't see any combat animations, and attack/damage is displayed through text boxes) so I didn't feel any nostalgia for it, and it wasn't really doing it for me.  But then, the game is only 7-9 hours long, and features everything else you could want out of a short-form old school RPG experience.  If you feel like a little nostalgic RPG runthrough, but don't want to dedicate 50+ hours, this game will do just fine.

Posted: November 10, 2012
												[Spoiler-Free Review]The spiritual successor to Breath of Death VII, Cthulhu Saves the World turns it's parodial focus to Lovecraft's ultimate evil-doer and dares you to pull it's finger.In addition to the much improved engine which brings the series more in line with it's 16-bit forefathers (bridges are now beautifully rendered), Cthulhu features a fleshed out campaign with an all-new cast of characters and plenty of post game bonus content for completionists everywhere. There's even a second quest with an all-new storyline once you've completed the first.I'll admit I'm not very well-versed in Cthulhuian lore and felt the humour was a bit too forced and goofy at times as a result. Where Breath of Death was sharp and witty, Cthulhu was brazen, outlandish and downright silly. Like a teenager trying to impress his friends with useless and mundane "skills".The music is still unconventionally memorable (hard rock cave music?) and nods to Zeboyd's history are strewn throughout the game. As with the first game, the optional developer's commentary is enlightening and entertaining and fits perfectly within a game unafraid to break the fourth wall.Cthulhu Saves the World is a bit of an enigma however, while I enjoyed it less than Breath of Death VII, I'm willing to admit it's probably more to do with my lack of understanding of the source material. I ended up playing this game nearly two times longer than I did Breath of Death VII and enjoyed most of it. Chances are if you've played the first game, you'll want to help Cthulhu Save the World too.Um... hurry?

Posted: January 31, 2015
												This is a fun, retro RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously.  However, it's not without problems.The plot is quirky and the dialog full of one-liners and bad puns.  The game is strongest during dialogue, with back and forths between the main characters and the narrator.  There are also plenty of lines when examing bookshelves and chest of drawers that will make you chuckle too.This game has great music (just had to make sure I mentioned that).The main problem I had with this game was the random encounters on places that weren't the world map.  These areas are giant labyrinths and you end up wandering around, lost, while getting pestered with battles.  After a while, you're strong enough that there's no great risk to these battles (although to be fair, I only played on Normal difficulty so other ones might be better in this regard) so you end up sighing, mashing Return and waiting for the damned battle to finish.A few hours into the game, I ended up working around the too frequent random battles by going to the start of each new area and selecting 'Fight' from the menu (which forces a new random encounter), getting all of them out of the way one after another.  This is a bit of a shame.I found myself surprisingly engaged in the story and characters but occasionally got yanked out of that state of mind with the grindy nature of the game.  Still, I'm glad I played this.This game is worth buying if you're into RPGs and are at a loss of the next one to play.

Posted: August 17, 2014
												If your in for a short but intriguing indie adventure, that's what your looking for. The battle system may not be so deep, the tech tree may not be so "branch-full": but c'mon you can unleash madness all over your foes, bind them in fear and kill them with just your presence (actually later on in the game may happen!). What else do you need? The story: if you take it lightheartedly you'll laugh and enjoy it all the way, plus most of the referencies and quotes speak for the effort of the writers. The commentaries (you need to switch them on at the beginning of the game) are short to read and help you feel closer to the concept of the game, sharing the path with the developer's notes. The monsters: awesome concept art and don't forget to read each and every monster description during the battle.The leveling-up mechanic: a fork (2 choiches) at every level give you options to build your party; some of the techniques your party can learn really add flavour to the gameplay (Cthulhu's Tentacles or Paws's Nuke). The music: epic, with some 90s flavour. Recommended to old RPG-lovers in for a break from too deep mechanics and to weird fiction addicts looking for a light and nice divertissement.

Posted: March 29, 2015
												This is probably one of my favourite games in my library.  Cthulhu Save the World is very well made.  Graphics are a throwback to SNES era graphics.  The sound is forgetable, but catchy and appropriate.  Gameplay is similar to other SNES generation turn-based RPGs.  In all aspects, Zeboyd Games showed massive improvements since Breath of Death.  The story is fun, well paced, and memorable.  Standard story mode takes around 7-10 hours to complete and you still have several bonus modes to keep you occupied afterwards.Bottomline: Cthulhu Saves the World is a must-have for any fan of the RPG genre.

Posted: December 8, 2014
												Did you grow up in the era where JRPs were the only decent RPGs on console systems? If names like Breath of Fire, Suidoken, Star Ocean and the like bring a warm feeling in your belly, then see a doctor. However, if the elicit a response of joy and fond after school memories, then I highly reccommend this game. I've been sick this week, and spent it playing this game, it reminded me of being sick as a kid and playing FF7, again.Zeboyd clearly made this game for fans of those games, but for those who don't have 40+ hours to spend trying to kill Ruby Weapon or get the damned golden chocobo. Clocks in at about 10-12 hours, and it can be a challenge if you try to speed through it. One boss, had me using all my potions and I barely survived.. The random battles can be frustrating, but luckily, after you reach x amount in a given area, the random battles stop. Not only that, but it is pretty funny to boot. Not bad for the two man team known as Zeboyd!
